children.title: Python
children.description:
1. The "What is Python?" (The Technical Definition)
Python is a high-level, interpreted, general-purpose programming language.
High-level: It uses English-like syntax, making it easy for humans to read.
Interpreted: Code is executed line-by-line, which makes debugging faster.
General-purpose: You can use it for almost anything—from web development to data science.

2. Why Choose Python? (The Selling Points)
Readability: Python’s motto is "readability counts." It uses indentation instead of curly braces, resulting in clean, uncluttered code.
Massive Library Support: Whether you want to build an AI (TensorFlow), analyze data (Pandas), or build a website (Django), there is already a "package" ready for you.
The Community: Being one of the most popular languages in the world means if you run into a bug, someone has already fixed it on Stack Overflow.

3. Real-World Applications
Artificial Intelligence: The backbone of ChatGPT and self-driving cars.
Data Science: Used by NASA to analyze planetary data and by Netflix to recommend movies.
Automation: Writing "scripts" to handle boring tasks like renaming thousands of files or scraping web data.

children.title: Virtual Environment
children.description:
A Virtual Environment is an isolated folder on your computer that contains its own specific version of Python and its own set of installed libraries.

Why Do We Need Them?
Avoid Version Conflicts: Project A might need Django 3.0, while Project B needs Django 5.0. You can't have both installed globally at the same time.
Reproducibility: When you share your code, a virtual environment ensures the other person knows exactly which versions of libraries you used.
Keep it Clean: It prevents your main operating system's Python from getting cluttered with hundreds of experimental packages.

How it works behind the scenes
When an environment is active, your computer changes its PATH variable. When you type python, it looks inside your project's .venv folder first rather than looking in the system's program files.
Global Environment	The Python installed on your whole computer. 
Local Environment	The .venv folder inside your project. Safe and isolated.
pip6	                         The tool used to install libraries into your environment.7
requirements.txt8	        A file that lists all your libraries so others can recreate your environment.9

children.content:
home = /Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/usr/bin
implementation = CPython
version_info = 3.9.6.final.0
virtualenv = 20.31.2
include-system-site-packages = false
base-prefix = /Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/Library/Frameworks/Python3.framework/Versions/3.9
base-exec-prefix = /Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/Library/Frameworks/Python3.framework/Versions/3.9
base-executable = /Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/Library/Frameworks/Python3.framework/Versions/3.9/bin/python3.9

# Keywords are reserved words that have a special meaning in Python. 
# You cannot use these as names for your variables or functions 
# because Python uses them to understand the structure of your code.

#As of Python 3.12, there are about 35 keywords. 
#Logic/Boolean
True, False, None, and, or, not
#Control Flow
if, else, elif, for, while, break, continue, return
#Structure
def (functions), class (objects), import (modules)
#Exceptions
try, except, finally, raise

children.title: Details
children.content:
Syntax is the set of rules that defines how a Python program is written. Python’s syntax is famous for being "clean."
A. Indentation (The Most Important Rule)
In most languages (Java, C++), you use curly braces {} to show which code belongs to a function or loop. 
In Python, we use spaces.
Standard practice is 4 spaces per level.
If your indentation is wrong, Python will throw an IndentationError.

B. Case Sensitivity
Python is case-sensitive. This means Variable, variable, and VARIABLE are three completely different things to Python.

C. Comments
Use the hash symbol (#) for single-line comments. Comments are ignored by the interpreter and are used to explain the "why" behind your code.
Python
# This is a comment - the computer ignores this
x = 10  # You can also put comments at the end of a line

D. Colons (:)
In Python, a colon marks the beginning of a new "block" of code (like an if statement, a for loop, or a function definition). The line following a colon must be indented.

# In Python, a variable is not a "box" in memory that holds a value. 
# Instead, a variable is a tag or name that references (or points to) a specific object in memory.
# Immutable Objects - int, float, str, etc...
# Mutable Objects - list, set, dict, etc...
# Must start with a letter (a-z, A-Z) or an underscore (_).
# Cannot start with a number.
# Can only contain alphanumeric characters and underscores (A-z, 0-9, and _).
# Names are case-sensitive (Age is different from age).
# Cannot use any of Python's reserved keywords (e.g., for, if, while, class).x = 5          # Integer
name = "Alice" # String
pi = 3.14      # Float
x = "hello"  # x is now a str 

# Use del to remove a variable
del x

# Use type() to check a variable’s type:
age = 30
print(type(age))  # <class 'int'>

# Use casting to convert types:
x = str(3)   # '3'
y = int("7") # 7
z = float("2.5") # 2.5

# Variable Scope
Global: Defined outside functions, accessible everywhere
Local: Defined inside functions, accessible only there
Nonlocal: Used in nested functions to refer to outer scope variables

# A tuple is an ordered, immutable collection with mixed types.
# Defined using parentheses () or the tuple() constructor.

my_tuple = (1, "apple", 3.14)

# Accessing
t = ("a", "b", "c")
print(t[0])     # "a"
print(t[-1])    # "c"
print(t[1:])    # ("b", "c")

# Packing
person = ("Alice", 30)

# Unpacking
name, age = person
print(name)  # "Alice"

# A list in Python is an ordered, indexed, mutable collection 
that can hold items of any data type — even mixed types.
my_list = [1, "hello", 3.14, True]
numbers = list((1, 2, 3))

# accessing by - By index (starts at 0)
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
print(fruits[0])  # "apple"
# Negative indexing:
print(fruits[-1])  # "cherry"
# Slicig
print(fruits[1:3])  # ["banana", "cherry"]

# funcitons
len()           # returns length of list
del list[1]     # removes the item at an index

# methods ....
append()	# Adds an item to the end
insert()	# Inserts item at specified index
remove()	# Removes first matching item
pop()	        # Removes item at index (default last)
sort()	        # Sorts the list
reverse()	# Reverses the list
clear()	        # Removes all items

# used to store data in key-value pairs
# they are ordered, mutable, indexed by key, with no duplicate keys
# values can be any type

person = {
    "name": "Alice",
    "age": 30,
    "city": "Glasgow"
}

# Accessing and modifying
print(person["name"])  # Alice
person["email"] = "alice@example.com"
del person["age"]

# get to avoid erros
print(person.get("phone", "Not found"))

# Looking through dictionaries
for key, value in person.items():
    print(f"{key}: {value}")

# They represent sequences of characters and are used extensively for text processing
# Use single, double, or triple quotes

s1 = 'Hello'
s2 = "World"
s3 = '''Multiline
string'''

# Access characters by index
s = "Python"
print(s[0])    # 'P'
print(s[-1])   # 'n'

# Slice substrings
print(s[1:4])  # 'yth'
print(s[:3])   # 'Pyt'

lower()	        Converts to lowercase
upper()	        Converts to uppercase
strip()	        Removes leading/trailing whitespace
replace(a, b)	Replaces substring a with b
split()	        Splits string into a list
join(list)	        Joins list into a string
find(sub)	Finds first index of sub
startswith()	Checks if string starts with a value
endswith()	Checks if string ends with a value
capitalize() – changes all string letters to capitals;
center()     – centers the string inside the field of a known length;
count()      – counts the occurrences of a given character;
join()       – joins all items of a tuple/list into one string;
lower()      – converts all the string's letters into lower-case letters;
lstrip()     – removes the white characters from the beginning of the string;
replace()    – replaces a given substring with another;
rfind()      – finds a substring starting from the end of the string;
rstrip()     – removes the trailing white spaces from the end of the string;
split()      – splits the string into a substring using a given delimiter;
strip()      – removes the leading and trailing white spaces;
swapcase()   – swaps the letters' cases (lower to upper and vice versa)
title()      – makes the first letter in each word upper-case;
upper()      – converts all the string's letter into upper-case letters.
endswith()   – does the string end with a given substring?
isalnum()    – does the string consist only of letters and digits?
isalpha()    – does the string consist only of letters?
islower()    – does the string consists only of lower-case letters?
isspace()    – does the string consists only of white spaces?
isupper()    – does the string consists only of upper-case letters?
startswith() – does the string begin with a given substring?

# Arithmatic operators
+ Addition: a + b
- Subtraction: a - b
* Multiplication: a * b
/ Division (float result): a / b
// Floor Division (integer result): a // b
% Modulus (remainder): a % b
** Exponentiation: a ** b

# Comparision operators
== Equal to
!= Not equal to
>, < Greater than / Less than
>=, <= Greater than or equal / Less than or equal

# Logical operators
and Returns True if both statements are true
or Returns True if at least one statement is true
not Reverses the result (True becomes False)

# Bitwise operators
& AND
| OR
^ XOR
~ NOT
<<, >> Shift left/right

# Membership operators
in Returns True if value is found
not in Returns True if value is not found

# Identity operators
is Returns True if both variables point to the same object
is not Returns True if they don’t

# lambda keyword lets you create anonymous functions
# functions without a name — in a single line. 
# These are especially useful for short, throwaway functions used as arguments to higher-order 
# functions like map(), filter(), or sorted().

lambda arguments: expression
square = lambda x: x ** 2
print(square(5))  # 25

# the backslash (\) is used as an escape character and for line continuation

# Basic Swap Using Tuple Unpacking
a = 5
b = 10

a, b = b, a

# None is a special constant that represents 
# the absence of a value or a null value. 
# It’s a built-in object of its own type — NoneType
# It’s a singleton, there’s only one instance of None in a Python program.
# You can assign it to variables to indicate “no value yet”
# Default return value of functions that don’t explicitly return anything
result = None

# global: This variable refers to the one in the global scope, not a new local one.
x = 10  # global variable

def update():
    global x
    x = 20  # modifies the global x

update()
print(x)  # Output: 20

# A class is a blueprint for creating objects
# An object is an instance of a class

class Dog:
    species = "Canine"  # class variable

    def __init__(self, name):
        self.name = name

dog1 = Dog("Buddy")
dog2 = Dog("Max")

print(dog1.species)  # Canine
print(dog2.species)  # Canine
print(dog1.name)      # Buddy


self.attribute	        Public (accessible from anywhere)
self._attribute	        Protected (internal use, not enforced)
self.__attribute	Private (name-mangled to prevent access)

# Use __ prefix for attributes that should be private.
# Provide getter/setter methods to access or modify private data safely.

__init__	             Object creation	Constructor, initializes attributes
__str__	                     str(obj) or print(obj)	Human-readable string representation
__repr__	             repr(obj) or in console	Unambiguous string for debugging
__len__	                     len(obj)	Length of object
__getitem__	             obj[key]	Indexing or key access
__setitem__	             obj[key] = value	Assigning to index/key
__delitem__	             del obj[key]	Deleting index/key
__eq__	                     obj1 == obj2	Equality comparison
__lt__	                     obj1 < obj2	Less-than comparison
__add__	                     obj1 + obj2	Addition
__call__	             obj()	Makes object callable like a function
__iter__	             for x in obj	Iteration
__next__	             next(obj)	Next item in iteration
__contains__	             x in obj	Membership test

# Python functions are blocks of reusable code designed to perform a specific task. 
# They help make your programs more organized, readable, and efficient.

def add(a, b):
    return a + b

result = add(3, 5)
print(result)  # 8

# Default parameters:
def greet(name="Guest"):
    print(f"Hello, {name}")

# Variable-length arguments
def add_all(*numbers):
    return sum(numbers)

# Lambda functions
square = lambda x: x * x
print(square(4))  # 16

python -m venv .venv
source .venv/bin/activate     
pip install requests
